reviewText:
Ok, after contacting the support repeatedly, I finally got the full-sized cards pdf.

The AR aspect is still not too reliable, but then it's a nonaiming camera/barcode combo, so it is damn good for that -- and putting in support for NFC or multi-pen tablets would have been rather extraneous as very few people have that equipment.

Having fun with kids. I'd say, the age bracket for this game is before they actually start learning chemistly, at least, from my memory of the course. I'll put it at about grade 5-6.

Let's see what other games in the series there will be.

Also, would really love to see more languages supported.

I first saw Professor Why at Hall of Games in WrocÅ‚aw in 2014. It was by far the best of the show and my kids spent a good deal of time there. To my surprise they managed to port the game on PC and it can now work with just any webcam.

This is not exactly a game, but a toy which is best played by kids together with their parents. This cooperativity begins early, as you and your kid will have to prepare the set of cards youself. This requires a printer, scissors, and a pair of small hands to manipulate them. We also applied some glue and cardboard. Great! Now it was ready to launch.

Immediately after running the game we noticed that our desktop is so much smaller than the large table available at the exhibition :). Also it turned out that in winter afternoons it quickly gets too dark for our webcam to recognize the card patterns efffectively. Last but not least, the game is a bit too fair" and incorrect combinations get recognized as easy as correct ones

The very idea of substracting points for mistakes in a game for kids relying and showing experimentation is horribly wrong. reviewText:
I wasn't exactly expecting much of this game when I bought it, but even then it disappointed.

This game attempts to teach you some basic chemistry in a semi-structured virtual setting. While the game accomplishes this the UI is very clunky and there are some annoying animations that hold you up. The UI doesn't work that well whilst trying to place materials together and sometimes penalises you for moving things to early. This is especially bad when the game moves things by itself and stuffs up your own tabletop arrangement.

Keep in mind that I've only played with the mouse, but let's face it, not many people are going to go to the hassle of printing out the cards that can be used with a webcam instead of a mouse, unless they're perhaps teaching children.

Perhaps the most annoying thing is the trivial animations shown before each experiment. Sure, this was probably for kids, but I'm sure most kids would get sick of this too, eventually.
